content: The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" establishes deductions for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code. The Act limits the amount allowed as a deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses for taxpayers in any taxable year. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" sets deductions for higher education expenses under the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction amount is limited based on modified adjusted gross income, with reductions for taxpayers exceeding certain income thresholds. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses based on modified adjusted gross income, with reductions for taxpayers exceeding specific income thresholds. Inflation adjustments are made to dollar amounts in certain cases after 2003. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses based on modified adjusted gross income, with reductions for taxpayers exceeding specific income thresholds. Section 222(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. Adjustments are made for inflation in certain cases after 2003. The "Make College Affordable Act of 2003" limits deductions for higher education expenses based on income. Section 222(a) of the Internal Revenue Code allows deductions for qualified tuition and related expenses of eligible students. The definition of eligible student is clarified in the Code. The deductions made by this Act are permanent and effective for payments after December 31, 2002. SEC. 25C. INTEREST ON HIGHER EDUCATION LOANS. The tax code allows individuals to claim a credit for interest paid on qualified education loans, with a maximum credit of $1,500. The credit amount is reduced for taxpayers with modified adjusted gross income over $50,000 ($100,000 for joint filers). The term 'modified adjusted gross income' excludes certain income sources. The credit amounts are adjusted for inflation annually. Dependents cannot claim the credit if a deduction for them is allowed. The credit under section 151 can be transferred to another taxpayer for the same taxable year. The credit is limited to the first 60 months of interest payments on a qualified education loan. Special rules include no double benefit and married couples must file a joint return. The taxpayer must be married and file a joint return with their spouse to claim the credit under subsection (a). Marital status is determined according to section 7703. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Sec. 25C allows for interest deduction on higher education loans, effective for loans incurred before or after the enactment of the Act, with the deduction applicable to interest payments due after December 31, 2002.
